summary: Email chain between defense attorney Andrew Patel and federal prosecutors regarding planned disclosures about Jeffrey Epstein in a criminal case. The discussion centers on redactions, protective orders, and concerns about client safety related to the release of information about Epstein meeting with prosecutors.

persons.context: Referred to as the client whose safety is of concern regarding disclosure of his meeting with prosecutors; notes mention his name being redacted.

connections.description: Patel is acting as defense attorney for Epstein, advocating for protective measures regarding disclosure of information.
Both copied on legal correspondence regarding case disclosures.

events.title: Email exchange about Epstein disclosures
events.description: Email chain discussing planned disclosure of notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein, with debates over redactions and potential protective orders.

keyFacts: Prosecutors planned to disclose redacted notes about Jeffrey Epstein to defense counsel on an 'Attorneys Eyes Only' (AEO) basis.
Andrew Patel expressed concerns about client safety if information about Epstein meeting with prosecutors was released.
The defense argued the material was not Brady, Rule 16, or 3500 material, but rather an error contradicted by surveillance video evidence.
Multiple redacted names appear in the email chain, indicating other individuals involved in the case whose identities are protected.
The correspondence references a protective order modeled on one from United States v. Madonna, 17 Cr. 89 (CS).
